posts.name: Prince M
posts.cooked:
Alliances could use transmitters or existing radios on their robots to communicate during a match, allowing them to share information effectively. A potential application could involve transmitting pose data, which could then be used in algorithms like pathfinding to help avoid collisions or navigate around other alliance members. This could also be useful toward the end of a match, enabling teams to coordinate actions such as climbing or parking without the need for verbal communication.  

Even if this practice isn't currently allowed, could FIRST Robotics Competition (FRC) consider making such communication standard in the future, or even establishing standardized protocols for robot-to-robot interaction? Personally, I believe this innovation would likely enhance the overall competitiveness of FIRST Robotics competitions.

posts.name: Fletch
posts.cooked:
In a hypothetical future where inter-robot communication was allowed, I would suggest against using a separate transmitter/receiver system and instead utilizing the existing wireless network. Currently, each team’s network is divided into VLANs, both wireless from the field to the robot and wired from the Driver Station (DS) to the field. There’s no inherent reason why FIRST (For Inspiration and Recognition of Science and Technology) couldn’t establish some form of communication across these VLANs. One could be created specifically for this purpose and integrated into WPILib to enable data sharing through that port.  

The main challenge with implementing such a system is the requirement for teams to agree on a common data format. To make it functional, the data format would need to be standardized, which is why integrating it into WPILib and allowing teams to toggle its use based on their preferences makes sense. This would give teams control over which data points are shared and possibly their sources, while ensuring consistency through standardized data structures.

posts.name: EricH
posts.cooked:
Actually, I think it’s possible to work around R707 and R706 by using the field radios, along with a bit of creativity and standardization when working with the Operator Console, particularly in its programming. R904 is likely to cause issues if you try this approach, so I’d advise against it. Honestly, I’d rather not end up being the CSA/FTA or HR representative at the first event where someone tries something similar, because then I’d have to reach out to HQ with a desperate plea for assistance.

The goal is to keep the original meaning intact while making the text more readable and properly formatted.

posts.name: Fletch
posts.cooked: I don't see how R904 (Operator console size/shape/etc) comes into play here. R706/R707 clearly prohibits any form of network traffic except what we're accustomed to (Driver Station)<->Robot via Field AP). If you're considering something but don't want to share it publicly, feel free to DM me. I'm definitely curious because I don't see any options given the current rules.

posts.name: Peter Johnson
posts.cooked: The R706/R707 standards only prohibit wireless communication.

posts.name: Mr. Siefen | 453
posts.cooked:
To set up a stable and efficient communication system, ensure that each driver station is connected to a separate local network and equipped with an additional Ethernet adapter. This setup isolates the system from interference with the robot network or the regular Ethernet adapter used by the driver station. Ideally, connect the driver station directly to the Field Management System (FMS) first to streamline communication and avoid delays during setup. Once connected, you can communicate effectively among team members, sharing robot data by routing messages through the driver station to others in the same network.

Avoiding wireless connections will enhance bandwidth and control, as direct wired communication reduces reliance on the field network infrastructure. Keep in mind that R706 is specifically designed for communication between the operator console and the robot, not for direct operator-to-operator interactions. Each operator console should independently manage its robot and monitor telemetry data within the Arena network, as this is both legal and practical.

On a side note, while tethering between robots can offer direct communication, it’s generally not recommended for competition settings, especially in games like FIRST Robotics. Opponents might tamper with the tether, and exceeding starting configuration limits could lead to penalties. Always adhere to the rules and plan accordingly.

posts.name: John Hascall (he)
posts.cooked: Semaphore flag detection built into Limelight 5?

I have always believed there is potential in establishing an alliance access level for NT and creating a more general access level. This setup could utilize the existing infrastructure and function wirelessly without transmitting data through other channels. 

The key aspect here is ensuring that a substantial number of teams adhere to established standards for the system to be effective.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Doubling the current limit does not make it work.

posts.name: Jim Sokoloff
posts.cooked: In qualifications, a significant number is necessary for their effectiveness. However, in eliminations, even 2 or 3 instances may hold value.

posts.name: Fletch
posts.cooked: R706 does not relate to wireless communication. Instead, it specifies that all signals must come from the OPERATOR CONSOLE and travel through the ARENA Ethernet network to reach the ROBOT. This system is specifically about communication between the operator console and the robot, not between operator consoles themselves. I originally interpreted the statement correctly by focusing on the term "signals," rather than limiting it to wireless or robot-to-robot communication.

posts.name: Jim Sokoloff
posts.cooked: Surely you agree that two drive coaches could talk to each other during a match without violating R706.

posts.name: Peter Johnson
posts.cooked:
Depends on the definitions of “signal” and “originate.” The signal (e.g., packet) sent to the ROBOT still originates in its respective [DS], as it is generated based on information other than human input. It seems reasonable to agree that sending a camera stream from the robot to the [DS] and performing image processing on the [DS] side before sending a signal back to the robot would be permissible, as it falls outside the restrictions outlined in G402.

Another consideration is utilizing the visual spectrum—perhaps having one [DS] display a QR code to another [DS]'s camera. While R905 does not explicitly exclude vision as an exception, it mainly addresses motion control via Kinect, so maybe one [DS] could wave a flag while the other uses a Kinect to detect it. Historically, [DS] vision systems have been allowed to provide information to the robot (as seen in event 254), so it’s unclear if this limitation was intentional.

posts.name: Fletch
posts.cooked: Yes, if we're talking strictly about the letter of the law, then technically, that is an exception. However, considering the rule's title, "Don’t bypass the ARENA network," it would be reasonable to assume we're discussing electrical signals here.

posts.name: Mr. Siefen | 453
posts.cooked:
If we asked the QA team, would they be able to provide a useful answer, or would they respond with the typical "We can't provide input on a hypothetical concept" type reply?

I’d like to understand where the line is drawn. For instance, if an IP camera is monitoring drivers and the image is processed on a <acronym>DS</acronym>, which stands for Driver Station, and then used to control the robot, while the laptop is connected to a separate camera outside the arena’s control system, potentially on a different subnet, achieving the same result is possible either with a dedicated DS laptop webcam or a plug-in USB device. As long as any commands sent to the robot go through the Driver Station and adhere to official protocols, why would that be considered illegal?

To me, the arena shouldn’t need to be part of every process. You can have external software on your computer that interfaces with custom controller boards, such as those from Arduino, via serial communication or as a direct HID keyboard, with button mappings acting as joysticks. If I wanted to replicate this functionality using a hard-line Ethernet connection and TCP/IP-based protocols, why would that differ? The arena isn’t required for this kind of operation and would only add unnecessary latency to the processing time.

posts.name: Ryan Blue
posts.cooked: The discussion revolves around determining ownership of an operator console, likely related to a gaming or control setup. Kingc95 suggests establishing a dedicated server with its own LAN switch and providing allies with Ethernet adapters, possibly to streamline connectivity. Fletch1373 questions how R904, potentially referring to console specifications, influences the size or design of the operator console. The size may relate to ergonomic needs, cable management, or console type, ensuring efficient setup and functionality.

posts.name: Jim Sokoloff
posts.cooked: The USB cable connecting our controller to the laptop’s USB hub is longer than 5 feet and we’ve gotten away with that on-paper violation every match. If the cabling length is the concern here, perhaps the driver will have to hold the switch to make it legal.

posts.name: Ryan Blue
posts.cooked: R904B states "excluding any items that are held or worn by the drivers during the match."

posts.name: Peter Johnson
posts.cooked: If the drivers on both teams hold onto the Ethernet cable, then rules lawyering is fun!

posts.name: Daniel G
posts.cooked:
Actually, for R904, since the OPERATOR CONSOLE is defined as “the set of COMPONENTS and MECHANISMS used by the DRIVERS and/or HUMAN PLAYERS to relay commands to the ROBOT,” I wonder if the neighboring “operator console” (in its common sense definition) that a team’s OPERATOR CONSOLE communicates with becomes part of that team’s defined OPERATOR CONSOLE. It makes sense that drivers would use the information produced by it to control the robot. Similarly, a screen displaying a dashboard would be part of the OPERATOR CONSOLE because drivers utilize it.

Granted, this might seem like an expansive interpretation of the term “use.” A more restrictive definition could limit it to COMPONENTS and MECHANISMS specifically intended for issuing commands, such as a driver’s laptop. However, the word “use” likely encompasses indirect uses, and I’d prefer not to argue against that interpretation. Even then, does that mean the tray upon which the laptop rests is considered “used”? That feels a bit far-fetched.

Still, there’s something to consider: if drivers on both teams are holding onto Ethernet cables, then perhaps they only need to share these cables to facilitate communication. This might resolve the issue for R904B (depth) but not R904A (length). 

This makes me wonder: if a hologram displaying information extending more than six feet and six inches off the ground were projected, would that be permissible? And can a COMPONENT be intangible? These questions challenge the boundaries of our current definition.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: the field reset life chose me (6201M, 3419A)

posts.name: Joe Johnson
posts.cooked:
I don’t want to hijack the thread, but I think the next logical step that FIRST could take is to have all robots on an alliance be able to publish information to each other. This could involve developing standards for message content and formatting, such as robot pose, robot velocities, and potentially even a system for sharing planned pathways.

I don’t believe this would significantly enhance robot capabilities in the first year such systems are introduced, but over two or three years, we could see many amazing behaviors that aren’t possible today.

data.title: Is it legal to have robot-to-robot communication?
